thread.title: Success of George Honeyman, Josh Maja and Lynden Gooch 'priceless' to Sunderland's academy

author: Stuart Rayner
title: Success of George Honeyman, Josh Maja and Lynden Gooch 'priceless' to Sunderland's academy
text:
Sport Success of George Honeyman, Josh Maja and Lynden Gooch 'priceless' to Sunderland's academy Paul Reid says the way George Honeyman, Josh Maja and Lynden Gooch have performed for the first team makes his job easier Share Lynden Gooch of Sunderland (right) celebrates with George Honeyman (Image: Sunderland AFC) Get Sunderland AFC updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
Having a captain, a top-scorer and a leading assist-maker who all came through the Academy of Light is “priceless”, says its manager Paul Reid.
The success of George Honeyman , Josh Maja and Lynden Gooch serves as an example to every youngster considering whether joining Sunderland will be good for their development.
“It’s priceless for us the fact we’ve got a manager (Jack Ross) who buys into the academy, buys into the youth aspect of it and is willing to give people a chance and reward people for good performances in the (under-)23s and the 18s,” Reid argues. Read More How helping the homeless and being more assertive can produce better Sunderland players
“It gives us physical evidence when we try to improve somebody. That’s our USP (unique selling point) at the moment, we can give them a pathway into the first team and there’s actual evidence of that. It’s not just a case of us saying that.
“We’ve averaged over five players from the academy in the first team this season and that’s massive. I’d like to see that stat against other teams in the league. Read More Sunderland still plan to shop abroad for young talent, but North East must be focus now
“Players like George Honeyman and Jordan Pickford (the goalkeeper who joined Everton in 2017) have got an identity with the club, and that’s what fans relate to. They know the community they represent and the fans can engage with that. To run a sustainable football club we need to produce our own players.
“As has been well documented by the owners, things that are happening in the world might dictate how we go down the academy route – things like Brexit might change the landscape completely. There could be even more of an onus to produce our own players.” Like us on Facebook
